Secs. 2-52—2-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PARLIAMENTARY PROCEDURE
Sec. 2-71. - Main motion. In order for the board to take any official action on any subject, a commissioner must propose a main motion. A proposed main motion will not be recognized by the chair until another commissioner agrees to second the motion. A second does not require the commissioner seconding the motion to support the motion. A commissioner may withdraw a main motion that he has made at any time before the board has voted on that motion. (Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-01, 6-12-2001) Sec. 2-72. - Debate. After the main motion is recognized by the chair, the board shall debate the motion. The debate shall be managed by the chairman in a manner that is fair to all members of the board. Commissioners can participate in the debate only when they are recognized by the chairman. During the course of debate, commissioners may introduce subsidiary motions as stated in section 2-75 that propose that the board take a particular action on a motion. There are two classes of subsidiary motions: debatable subsidiary motions and undebatable subsidiary motions. Debatable subsidiary motions consist of motions to postpone indefinitely, amend, refer to committee, and postpone to a time certain. Debatable subsidiary motions require a second before they can be voted on or debated. There are three undebatable subsidiary motions: limit debate, vote immediately, and lay on the table. They require a second and cannot be debated. Commissioners may also introduce privileged motions as stated in section 2-76. Privileged motions facilitate the running of the meeting and can be introduced during the course of debate. Privileged motions consist of a motion to raise a question of privilege and motions to recess and adjourn. The motions to recess and adjourn require a second. Debate is not allowed on privileged motions. (Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-02, 6-12-2001) Sec. 2-73. - Voting procedure. Voting on debatable motions and voting on undebatable motions shall take place in accordance with the following provisions: (1) Debatable motions. In the case of debatable motions, the vote can be proposed in one of two ways: If debate has been completed and no other commissioner wishes to speak, the chair can call for the vote. If there are no objections then the chair can proceed with the vote. If the chairman calls for the vote and there is an objection, a member of the board may move to vote immediately (move the previous question). If this motion is seconded and approved by a two-third votes, debate will stop. The chairman will then read the proposed motion to the board and ask for the votes of the commissioners. (2) Undebatable motions. In the case of undebatable motions, the vote shall occur immediately after the motion is recognized by the chair. The chairman shall read the proposed motion to the board and then call for the vote. (Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-03, 6-12-2001) Sec. 2-74. - Ranking of motions. Each subsidiary and privileged motion is assigned a specific rank. A motion of higher precedence can interrupt a motion of lower precedence. The higher motion must be decided before the board returns to consider the motion of lower precedence. A main motion has the lowest rank and does not take precedence over any other motion. A motion to adjourn has the highest rank and will take precedence over all subsidiary and privileged motions. The order of precedence of motions shall be in accordance with this section. Motions at the top of the following list take precedence over motions at the bottom of the list:
(Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-04, 6-12-2001) Sec. 2-75. - Subsidiary motions. During the course of debate, commissioners may introduce motions that propose that the board take a particular action on a main motion. These motions are called subsidiary motions and they allow a board to reach a conclusion on the main motion. Subsidiary motions require a second before they can be voted on or debated. Three subsidiary motions, amend, limit debate and vote immediately, also can apply to other subsidiary motions. (1) Postpone indefinitely. If a commissioner believes that the main motion should not be considered by the board, that commissioner may move to postpone the consideration of the main motion indefinitely. If the motion is successful, consideration of the main motion stops and the main motion is tabled for the duration of the meeting. A motion to postpone indefinitely can be debated but it cannot be amended. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. (2) Amend. If a commissioner believes that a main motion that is on the table should be changed in order to make it more acceptable, he can move to amend the motion. Amendments must be closely related to the original motion and must not change the nature of the motion that they amend. Motions to refer, amend, postpone to a time certain and the motion to recess can also be amended. A motion cannot be amended more than two times. Debate is allowed on a motion to amend only if the original motion is debatable. Debate is limited to the proposed amendment. A majority vote is required for the board to adopt an amendment. If the amendment is adopted then the board shall consider the amended version of the motion. (3) Refer to a committee (commit). If a commissioner believes that further information is needed before the board can act on a main motion, he may propose that the motion be referred to a specific committee or department for further study. If an appropriate committee does not already exist, then a committee may be formed as a part of the motion. A motion to commit should specify the date that the committee or department will report back to the board. This motion is debatable and amendable. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. (4) Postpone to a time certain (postpone definitely). A motion to postpone to a certain time may be proposed if a commissioner believes that the main motion should be considered until a future time. This motion shall set a particular time for the main motion to be considered again. It is debatable and can be amended. If this motion is passed, the chairman will bring the original motion back to the board for consideration at the specified time which may be at the same meeting, at a subsequent meeting, or upon the occurrence of a specified time which may be at the same meeting, at a subsequent meeting, or upon the occurrence of a specified event. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. (5) Limit or extend limits of debate. A motion to limit debate places a time constraint on the length of debate. The details of such a motion are to be decided by the commissioner who makes the motion. This motion can also be used to extend the limits of debate if a limit on debate already exists. Debate is not allowed on this motion and a two-thirds vote is required. (6) Vote immediately (previous question). If a commissioner believes debate on a motion should end and that the motion being considered should be voted on, the commissioner can move to vote immediately. The motion is undebatable and a vote of two-thirds of the board is required for the motion to pass. (7) Lay on the table (postpone temporarily). A motion to lay on the table proposes that the consideration of a main motion be postponed until a later time in the same meeting. The main motion can be brought back for consideration only if a motion to resume consideration is accepted by the board during the same meeting. The motion will die if it is not taken up during the meeting. Debate is not allowed on this motion and the motion is not amendable. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. (Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-05, 6-12-2001) Sec. 2-76. - Privileged motions. Privileged motions facilitate the running of the meeting. They do not address or relate to a main motion and can be introduced whether or not there is a main motion under consideration. Privileged motions take precedence over all subsidiary motions. Debate is not allowed on these motions. (1) Question of privilege. A formal question addressed to the chair concerning the rights of a commissioner or of the board as a whole is referred to as a question of privilege. It does not require a second and cannot be debated or amended. The chair is required to make a ruling on the question. (2) Recess. A motion to recess proposes that the meeting be suspended for a particular amount of time when business is still pending. It is a temporary intermission of the proceedings. The motion must specify the length of the recess. The motion must also be seconded. Debate is not allowed on this motion but the motion can be amended. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. (3) Adjourn. In order for a meeting to come to a close, a commissioner must make a motion to adjourn. The motion to adjourn has the highest rank of any motion and as a result it can be introduced at any time. The motion requires a second, but is not debatable or amendable. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. (Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-06, 6-12-2001) Sec. 2-77. - Incidental motion. Incidental motions allow commissioners to exert their rights as a member of the board. Incidental motions can be introduced at any time during a meeting. (1) Appeal. If a commissioner disagrees with a ruling that is made by the chair, that commissioner may appeal the decision. If the appeal is seconded, the appeal will be considered by the board. The chair has the opportunity to explain the ruling that has been challenged. The board may then debate the appeal. The board shall decide by majority vote if the chair's decision is to be upheld or overturned. An appeal is high in precedence and can only be interrupted by a privileged motion or by a motion to lay on the table. (2) Parliamentary inquiry. If a commissioner has a question about the rules of order, he may ask the chair to give an opinion on that question. This question should take the form of a parliamentary inquiry and should relate to the current business of the board. This motion takes precedence over all motions except privileged motions. This motion does not require a second and is not debatable or amendable. (3) Point of order (question of order). If a commissioner believes that a violation of the rules of parliamentary procedure has occurred, he can raise a point of order. A second is not required. The chair can make a ruling on the question or can allow the board to debate and then rule on the question by majority vote. A point of order can only be interrupted by a privileged motion or a motion to lay on the table. (4) Point of information (request for information). If a commissioner has a question about the facts of a particular issue that is being considered, he may ask a point of information. This motion is addressed first to the chair and then to the appropriate person. A second is not required and the motion is not debatable or amendable. (Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-07, 6-12-2001) Sec. 2-78. - Supplementary main motions. Three motions allow the board to act on a main motion that has either been passed or tabled by the board. These motions are considered to be main motions but differ from usual main motions in the ways specified. (1) Reconsider. The motion to reconsider allows the board to debate whether or not to overturn a decision made at the meeting that is in progress. It allows the board to consider new information that may affect the decision that has already been made. Any commissioner can make a motion to reconsider and any commissioner may second the motions. The motion is debatable but it cannot be amended. A majority vote of the board is required for the motion to pass. If a motion to reconsider is passed, the original decision will be voided and the board will return to debate and revote the original motion. (2) Rescind. A motion to rescind proposes that the board overturn a motion passed at a previous meeting. A motion to rescind can be made by any commissioner. It is in order as long as the original motion has not been implemented. An announcement of the intention to rescind a motion may be made at the meeting where the decision was made, or the commissioner seeking to rescind may place the matter on the agenda for the next meeting. The motion to rescind will then be placed on the agenda for the next meeting. At the next meeting, the motion to rescind will formally be made. If it is seconded, then the board shall debate and vote on rescission. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. If a motion to rescind is passed, the original decision will be voided. (3) Resume consideration. The motion to resume consideration allows the board to consider a motion that has been temporarily postponed. This motion requires a second and is not debatable or amendable. It is a main motion but ranks higher than any debatable motion. A majority vote is required for the motion to pass. (Ord. No. 2001-010, § 1-08, 6-12-2001) Secs. 2-79—2-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS
Sec. 2-101. - Penalty. A person who, by refusing to abide by the terms of this division, recklessly or knowingly commits any act which can reasonably be expected to prevent or disrupt a meeting of the board of commissioners may be prosecuted under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34, and upon conviction, punished as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 9) Sec. 2-102. - Open to the public. All meetings of the board of commissioners shall be open to the public as required by O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1. Members of the public are encouraged to attend the meetings of the board, but shall not speak or address the board without the express consent of the chairman of the board of commissioners, or in the chairman's absence, the express consent of the member of the board acting as chairman for that meeting, and in accordance with this division. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 1) Sec. 2-103. - Agenda. The meetings of the board of commissioners shall be conducted in accordance with a written agenda prepared by, or at the direction of, the county administrator. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 2) Sec. 2-104. - Comment and question period. In order for the board of commissioners to hear the opinions and concerns of the citizens of the county and other members of the public and to facilitate the orderly conduct of the board's business, the board shall schedule one or more periods of a specified length of time during each meeting for brief comments and questions from the public. No single member of the public or group representative shall be permitted more than five minutes to speak at any single meeting of the board. Questions calling for specific or detailed answers, and requests calling for specific action, that are not presented to the board of commissioners in accordance with section 2-105, are not encouraged and may not be considered, because the board may not have the information readily available to it to give a complete answer or to make an informed decision. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 3) Sec. 2-105. - Requests, complaints and questions to be submitted to county administrator. Members of the public wishing to make formal presentations before the board of commissioners and those who desire the board to consider specific or detailed questions or requests shall contact the county administrator at least five days prior to the meeting in order to permit the matter to be placed on the agenda for the meeting. All requests, complaints and questions to come before the board of commissioners shall be presented in writing to the county administrator at least five days prior to the meeting at which they are to be considered. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 4) Sec. 2-106. - Topic. Comments, questions, and requests at the regular meetings of the board of commissioners may concern any topic relating to the operation of the county. Comments, questions and requests at any special meeting of the board shall concern only the topic with which the special meeting is concerned. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 5) Sec. 2-107. - Spokesperson. Members of the public who share a common concern, question or request are encouraged to designate a spokesperson. All persons representing others or such groups shall identify the person or group for whom they are speaking. All persons addressing the board shall identify themselves. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 6) Sec. 2-108. - Responsibility of chairman. The chairman of the board of commissioners, or in his absence, the member of the board acting as chairman for that meeting, shall have the responsibility to call on all members of the public wishing to address the board in accordance with this division, the responsibility to maintain order, and the responsibility to adhere to the time limitations set forth in this division. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 7) Sec. 2-109. - Response to questions. Questions capable of an immediate reply shall be answered by the chairman or referred to other members of the board or staff present at the meeting for reply. Those questions requiring further information or consideration than then available to the board shall be answered when such information is available or adequate consideration given to the matter. (Ord. of 2-10-1998, § 8) Secs. 2-110—2-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - AUTHORITIES, BOARDS, AND COMMISSIONS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Animal control board, § 14-33; planning commission, § 54-161 et seq. State Law reference— Code of ethics for government service, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1 et seq.; code of ethics for members of boards, commissions and authorities, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-3.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-131—2-150. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY OF MITCHELL COUNTY[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Mitchell County Development Authority, Related Laws, Article III. State Law reference— Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.; georgia Development Authority Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-10-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-151. - Findings. (a) It has been determined by the board of commissioners that there exists an urgent need to develop and promote for the public good and general welfare trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities within the county. (b) There has existed for several years in the county a public corporation known as the Mitchell County Development Authority created by an amendment to the state constitution (1962 Ga. Laws, page 761) for the purpose of encouraging and promoting the expansion and development of industry, agriculture, trade, and commerce within the county. (c) The Mitchell County Development Authority has acted in carrying out its specified purpose within the limitations and restrictions set forth in the particular amendment to the state constitution which provided for its creation and operation. (d) The amendment to article VII, section VII of the state constitution which permits the general assembly of the state to create development authorities for certain purposes and which was ratified at the general election of November 5, 1968, and thereafter duly proclaimed by the governor of the state (1968 Ga. Laws, page 1606), and the Development Authorities Law (1969 Ga. Laws, page 137) O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq., which was enacted by the general assembly of the state pursuant to authority granted in such constitutional amendment, authorize each county and each municipal corporation in the state to activate development authorities within each such county and municipal corporation, such development authorities having been created upon the adoption and approval of the Development Authorities Law. (e) The Development Authorities Law, as amended, grants broader powers in the area of general industrial development to development authorities created thereunder than are granted under the terms of the constitutional amendment creating the Mitchell County Development Authority and the board of commissioners is desirous of having two authorities in the county which can be used to promote and develop for the public good and welfare trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the county. (f) The board of commissioners, after thorough investigation, has determined that it is desirable and necessary that the Development Authority of Mitchell County be activated immediately in order to fulfill the present needs expressed in this division. (Res. of 7-24-1973) Sec. 2-152. - Declaration of need. There is determined and declared to be a pressing, existing and future need for a development authority, as more fully described and defined in the Development Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.), to function in the county for the purpose of developing and promoting for the public good and general welfare trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the county thereby promoting the general welfare of the citizenry. (Res. of 7-24-1973) Sec. 2-153. - Activated. There is activated in the county the public body corporate and politic known as the Development Authority of Mitchell County which was created upon the adoption and approval of the Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. (Res. of 7-24-1973) Sec. 2-154. - Composition of board; terms; successors. There shall be seven members elected to the board of directors of the Development Authority of Mitchell County none of whom shall be an officer or employee of the county. The initial directors shall serve for terms of two years, four years and six years and thereafter for staggered terms of six years. If, at the end of any term of office of any director, a successor thereto shall not have been elected, then the director whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his successor shall be so elected. (Res. of 7-24-1973) Sec. 2-155. - Duties and responsibilities. The board of directors elected pursuant to this division shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Development Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.) as it now exists and as it might hereafter be amended or modified. (Res. of 7-24-1973) Sec. 2-156. - Affect. Action taken by the board of commissioners as specified in this division is not intended in any way to affect the Mitchell County Development Authority, including, without limitation, its existence, purpose, organization, powers or function. (Res. of 7-24-1973) Secs. 2-157—2-180. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY
Sec. 2-181. - Provisions saved from repeal. The ordinance creating the Joint Development Authority of Brooks, Colquitt, Grady, Mitchell and Thomas Counties, together with all amendments thereto, is not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the county. DIVISION 4. - HOSPITAL AUTHORITY
Sec. 2-182. - Members. (a) The Mitchell County Hospital Authority shall have 15 voting members plus three ex officio members, which ex officio members shall be the Chief of Staff of the Mitchell County Hospital, the Mitchell County Hospital Administrator, and the administrative assistant to the hospital administrator. (b) The members of the Mitchell County Hospital Authority shall be appointed by the Mitchell County Board of Commissioners with each commissioner having nominated three members to serve on said authority. (Res. No. 2003-036, §§ 1, 2, 7-8-2003) Sec. 2-183. - Terms of office. Members of the hospital authority shall serve four-year terms, which term shall commence on July 1 on the year of their appointment and shall terminate on the 30th of June four years from the date on which such term began, provided, however, that seven of the 15 members of the hospital authority appointed immediately following the adoption of this resolution shall serve only a two-year term, from July to June two years afterward, with their successors in office then serving four years, so as to stagger the appointment of members to the hospital authority. The respective commissioners from commissioners districts one, two and three shall each nominate two members to serve on the Hospital Authority for four years and one to serve two years, and the respective commissioners for commissioner districts four and five shall nominate one member to serve four years and two to serve two years, and the appointment of the members to the hospital authority immediately following the passage of this resolution. (Res. No. 2003-036, § 3, 7-8-2003) Sec. 2-184. - Manner of appointment. (a) Although not binding on the board of commissioners, the hospital authority may recommend persons to the board of commissioners or to the commissioners having the authority to nominate members for the hospital authority, for the consideration of the commissioners having authority to nominate members of the hospital authority. (b) The board of commissioners shall seek to appoint well-qualified persons to the hospital authority which reflect the broad cross section of the citizenry of this county. (Res. No. 2003-036, § 4, 5, 7-8-2003) Sec. 2-185. - Method of filing vacancies. The Mitchell County Board of Commissioners shall appoint persons to fill out the unexpired term of any member of the hospital authority who fails to complete his or her full term, with the commissioner serving in the district whose commissioner nominated the person whose unexpired term is being filled having the power to nominate the successor. (Res. No. 2003-036, § 6, 7-8-2003) Secs. 2-186—2-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE[5] Footnotes: --- (5) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the county or any evidence of the county's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-7(2); taxation, ch. 70. State Law reference— Multiyear lease, purchase or lease purchase contracts, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-13; local government budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; local government finance generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; establishment of fiscal year required, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-3(a); appointment of budget officer, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-4; preparation of proposed budget, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-5; adoption of budget ordinance or budget resolution, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-6; accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-1 et seq.; designation of depository, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-14; purchases through state, O.C.G.A. § 50-5-100 et seq.; power of expenditure, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ II.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-201—2-220. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING POLICIES AND PROCEDURES
Sec. 2-221. - Approval required. (a) No officer or employee of the county shall purchase for or on behalf of the county administrator or his office any materials, supplies, goods, wares, merchandise or equipment of any kind or character except through the approval of the county administrator or, in his absence the clerk, but as previously approved by the county administrator, except for emergencies as provided in this division. No voucher check or other method of payment shall be honored if this method is not followed. (b) It shall be considered a breach of duty on the part of any officer or employee of the county to make any purchase or aid and abet the making of any purchase by any other manner than through the county administrator or, at his direction the clerk, except as provided in emergency purchases as defined in section 2-223. (c) Purchases up to $3,000.00 may be approved by the county administrator or, at his direction the clerk, without approval from the board of commissioners provided that same is a budgeted item. Any purchase over $3,000.00 shall require the approval of the board of commissioners, except that in emergency situations, as provided in this division, the approval of the chairman of the board of commissioners and the vice-chairman of the board of commissioners may authorize the purchase. (d) The officer or employee desiring to make a purchase shall first submit to the county administrator a requisition form to be provided by the county administrator which form shall identify the officer or employee seeking the purchase, the department for which the purchase is sought, at least three bids on the item to be purchased or explanation as to why bids were not obtained, the quantity of items sought to be purchased, the purchase price of each unit and the total price and any other information required by the county administrator. Upon approval of the requisition, the county administrator or, at his direction the clerk, shall issue the purchase order. (e) All invoices shall be turned in on a daily basis and shall be attached to the purchase orders. All such invoices shall be submitted to the county administrator. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 1) Sec. 2-222. - Purchase orders required. (a) No officer or employee of the county shall request any merchant, dealer or other vendor to deliver goods to the county or any department, officer or employee thereof, except on a regular purchase order approved by the county administrator, except as provided in this division for emergencies. (b) All purchase orders must be executed by the county administrator or, at his direction the clerk. (c) Any purchases made without obtaining a purchase order in advance shall be disallowed and payment refused. No purchase order will be issued after the fact. Vendors, merchants and dealers will be deemed to have dealt with any employee or officer who does not have a purchase order at their own risk. (d) Violation of any provision of this division shall be determined a violation of the county personnel policy and shall be deemed sufficient grounds for discharge. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 2) Sec. 2-223. - Emergency purchases. In all cases where there is an immediate need for any materials, supplies, goods, wares or merchandise by any department, such department must advise the county administrator, and if he cannot be located, the officer or employee must immediately notify the chairman or vice-chairman of the board of commissioners for action pursuant to section 2-221(c). If none of the above can be reached and the purchase of the item is absolutely necessary, such purchase must be reported to the county administrator within 24 hours of such purchase. An emergency is defined as being a situation where immediate action is absolutely necessary and delay would adversely affect the life, health or safety of the citizens of the county. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 3) Sec. 2-224. - Discretion on purchases. In all purchases where quality as well as price and service is involved, the county administrator or, at his direction the clerk, shall exercise discretion in making the purchase. In all cases where patented items or special purpose items are requested, the county administrator or, at his direction the clerk, has the discretionary authority to decide whether similar products of equal quality and at a lower price shall be ordered in lieu of items requested. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 4) Sec. 2-225. - Competitive bids and exceptions. (a) It shall be the duty of the county administrator or, at his direction the clerk, to make all purchases in excess of $500.00 on competitive bids, except in the case of emergency purchases as described in section 2-223. (b) All bids for goods and materials purchased by the county shall be kept on file in the county administrator's office and shall be subject to inspection at any time. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 5) Sec. 2-226. - Bidding procedures. (a) Notices. Notices inviting bids shall be published in at least one official newspaper in the county at least five days preceding the last day for the receipt of proposals. The newspaper notice shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold, shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured, and the time and place for opening bids. In all cases, a notice inviting bids will be posted in an appropriate place within the county courthouse at least ten days preceding the last day for the receipt proposals. (b) Solicitation. The county administrator shall solicit bids from all prospective vendors and contractors by mailing them copies of bids with the necessary specifications, and any other information which will acquaint them with proposed purchases. (c) Bid deposits. When deemed necessary by the county administrator, bid deposits shall be prescribed in the public notices inviting bids. The amounts of such deposits shall be ten percent of the bids and shall be in the form of a bond or certified check. Bonds and certified checks shall be returned to unsuccessful bidders within five days after the awarding of the contracts. The successful bidder shall forfeit deposits required upon failure on his part to enter into a contract within 15 days after the award. (d) Bid receiving and opening. Bids shall be sealed, shall be identified on the envelope, shall be submitted at the place and no later than the time specified in the public notice inviting bids and shall be opened at a public meeting at the time and place stated in the public notice. A tabulation of all bids received shall be made available for public inspection. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 6) Sec. 2-227. - Award of contract. In all cases in which bids are solicited and received, the contract shall be awarded to the lowest bidder unless: (1) Two or more bids have the lowest bid, in which case, if one of the lowest bids is from a bidder from the county, then the contract shall be awarded to that local bidder, and if none of the lowest bids are from a local bidder, then the contract shall be submitted again for bids; or (2) All bids are rejected. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 7; Ord. of 2001-027, 8-21-2001) Sec. 2-228. - Sale of county property. (a) No property belonging to the county shall be sold except after approval of the board of commissioners. (b) When any property owned by the county has become surplus, unserviceable or useless, the head of the department in charge of the property shall certify to the board of commissioners that such property is no longer useful and should be disposed of. Any property to be sold shall be sold at public sale either by sealed bid or public outcry to the highest bidder for cash, except nothing in this section shall prevent the county from donating or exchanging such surplus property with other governmental units or quasigovernmental units. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 8) Secs. 2-229—2-250. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT POLICIES
Sec. 2-251. - Background. The financial management policies of this division establish the overall basic framework for the financial management of the county. These policies will provide assistance to the board of commissioners and department heads by providing guidance in the decision-making process of the county. These policies will provide guidelines for evaluating both current activities and proposals for future programs. Most of the policies listed in this division represent long-standing principles and practices which have guided the county in the past and have helped maintain its financial stability over the years. These policies shall be reviewed annually by the board of commissioners and changes made as the board deems appropriate. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1)) Sec. 2-252. - Operating budget policies. An operating budget shall be adopted annually by the board of commissioners. Such budget shall be balanced in all funds. The operating budget authorizing the expenditure of county monies shall be adopted annually not later than the last board of commissioners meeting in the fiscal year preceding the fiscal year to which the budget applies. Priority for funding in the operating budget shall be given to essential services. The county will maintain sufficient budgetary control systems to ensure adherence to the budget and will prepare and distribute reports comparing the budget with actual on a monthly basis. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1)) Sec. 2-253. - Capital budget policies. A capital improvements plan for a five-year period shall be adopted and updated annually by the board of commissioners. Except in emergencies, no capital purchase may be made for items not included in the capital improvements plan. The capital improvements plan will provide for the adequate maintenance and orderly replacement of capital plant and equipment from current revenues where possible. Priorities for funding in the capital improvements plan shall be determined by the board of commissioners. The board of commissioners will annually appropriate an amount not less than $100,000.00 to the capital improvements project fund from the general revenues of the county. Appropriations from the capital improvements project fund shall be made at the discretion of the board of commissioners. For an item to be considered a capital improvement it must have a minimum useful life of 24 months and/or a minimum cost of $10,000.00. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1)) Sec. 2-254. - Reserve policies. There shall be established in the general fund a reserve for contingencies account to provide for unanticipated expenditures of a nonrecurring nature. Appropriations to the reserve for contingencies account shall be accumulated until the balance in the account reaches a level of $100,000.00 and shall be maintained at that level thereafter. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1)) Sec. 2-255. - Debt policies. The county shall take a very conservative and cautious stance toward debt, incurring debt only when necessary. The term of any longterm debt incurred by the county shall not exceed the expected useful life of the asset for which the debt is incurred and shall be limited to capital improvements only. Shortterm debt shall be limited to tax anticipation note purposes only. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1)) Sec. 2-256. - Purchasing policies. All purchases by the county shall be made in accordance with the rules and regulations as set out in the purchasing ordinance adopted by the board of commissioners and on file in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1)) Sec. 2-257. - Accounting, auditing and financial reporting policies. The county's financial reports shall comply with generally accepted accounting practices (GAAP) as outlined in governmental accounting, audition and financial reporting (GAAFR). An independent audit of the county's financial records shall be performed annually. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1)) Sec. 2-258. - Cash management policy. Collection, disbursement and deposit of all county funds shall be managed to meet anticipated cash flow needs. The county will strive to maximize the return on its investments, with the primary objective being preserving capital in accordance with the county's ordinances and prudent investment practices. All investments of county funds shall be made through financial institutions located within the county provided that the rates are reasonably competitive with the state investment pool. The county will encourage competition among the financial institutions for the county's investments and depository accounts. Investments can only be made in money market accounts and certificates of deposit that are federally insured and/or covered by pledged securities. (Ord. of 5-11-1993(1))

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcoholic beverage means malt beverages and wine. Consumption on premises means the consumption of malt beverages or wine within the building wherein the same is sold and allows the licensee to pour the contents of the original package into a glass, mug or other container from which such beverages are customarily consumed and further allows the licensee to charge its customers by the glass, mug or other container from which such beverages are consumed. Malt beverages or wine purchased for consumption on premises shall not be taken or consumed outside the building wherein the same is sold. Malt beverages means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than six percent alcohol by volume, and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, malt beer, and strong beer, but not including sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Packaged and by the package mean by the bottle, can, keg, barrel, or other original consumer container which shall not be opened inside the building where the same is sold nor on property outside of such building which is owned, rented, or controlled by the license holder. Wine means an alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term "wine" does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 101, 12-11-2001) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Secs. 6-2—6-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EXCISE AND LICENSE TAXES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 70.
Sec. 6-31. - Wholesale malt beverages and wine. (a) There is levied and imposed upon all wholesale malt beverages dealers an excise tax in the amount of $0.4166 per ounce of malt beverages sold by such wholesale dealers within the county. (b) There is levied and imposed upon all wholesale wine dealers an excise tax in the amount of $0.22 per liter, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter, of wine sold by such wholesale dealers within the county. (c) Each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages or wine in the county shall file a report by the tenth day of each month showing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages and wine, by size and type of container, constituting a beginning and ending inventory for the month, sold within the county. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the county on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this article. (d) No decal, stamp, or other identifying marking shall be required on malt beverages or wine sold within the county. (e) The excise tax provided for in this section shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages or wine at retail or wholesale, within the county. (f) The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due during the first 30-day period following the date such report and remittance were due and a further penalty of ten percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive 30-day period or any portion thereof during which such report and remittance are not filed. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to 50 percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 201, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-32. - Retail beer and wine dealers. (a) There is levied and imposed upon each retail malt beverage dealer within the county a privilege and license tax in the amount of $250.00 for the sale of malt beverages by the package only, a privilege and license tax in the amount of $250.00 for the sale of malt beverages for consumption on premises only, and a privilege and license tax in the amount of $500.00 for the sale of malt beverages by the package and for consumption on premises. The taxes imposed shall be paid with the license applications and annually thereafter on January 1. (b) There is levied and imposed upon each retail wine dealer within the county a privilege and license tax in the amount of $250.00 for the sale of wine by the package only and a privilege and license tax in the amount of $250.00 for the sale of wine for consumption on premises only and a privilege and license tax in the amount of $500.00 for the sale of wine by the package and for consumption on premises. The taxes imposed shall be paid with the license application and annually each year thereafter on January 1. (c) Any other provisions of this Code to the contrary notwithstanding, the annual license taxes referred to in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be nonprorated license taxes and the full amount of the taxes will be required to be paid regardless of what time of year the licenses are issued. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 202, 12-11-2001) Secs. 6-33—6-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LICENSES
Sec. 6-61. - Punishment for violation. The violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be unlawful and shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 401, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-62. - Required; revocation and suspension. (a) The privilege of engaging in the business of a retail malt beverage or wine dealer shall in no event be granted to any person except by the issuance of a license as provided in this article, and such privilege shall be held and enjoyed by the licensee only so long as such licensee shall comply fully with the requirements of this article and promptly pay all taxes provided for in this article. (b) No retail malt beverage or wine license shall be issued: (1) To a person who has been convicted of any felony within a period of ten years immediately prior to the filing of such application, or to a person who has been convicted of sale of an alcoholic beverage to a minor within a period of five years immediately prior to the filing of such application, whether as a state offense or violation of a municipal ordinance, or to a person who has been convicted of any two other misdemeanors or violations of municipal or county ordinances, except minor traffic violations, within a period of five years immediately prior to the filing of such application. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "convicted" or "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty, or a plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of bond. (2) A person or firm whose place of business is conducted by a manager or other employees, unless such manager or other employees possess the same qualifications required by the license holder. By making application for a license under this article, an applicant, his manager and other employees consent and subject themselves to an investigation by the sheriff's department for the purpose of determining the fitness of the holder of the license or his manager or employees, to be granted such license or to manage or be employed in the licensed location, as the case may be. (3) For a location not properly zoned for the conduct of the business contemplated in the application. (4) For a location that does not have sufficient parking to accommodate the patrons of the business contemplated in the application. (5) For a location at which a previous alcoholic beverage license has been revoked or suspended unless the conditions which led to the previous revocation or suspension of such license no longer exist. (6) Where the granting of such license would constitute a violation of state law or regulation, or where there is a failure to meet the requirements for a state license for the sale of alcoholic beverages. (7) To any person or firm seeking an alcoholic beverage license authorizing consumption on the premises unless such person or firm agrees to the suspension and surrender of such person's or firm's business license as provided in subsection (f) of this section. (8) To any person who provides false information in his application for an alcoholic beverage license, or in any documents attached thereto, or who fails to pay the required fees and taxes. (9) For any location within 100 yards of any school building, schoolgrounds, college campus, or alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by this state or any county or municipal government in this state, as measured by a straight line from the property line of the tract on which is located the business seeking an alcoholic beverage license to the property line of such school building, schoolgrounds, college campus, or alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by this state or any county or municipal government in this state. (c) Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, an alcoholic beverage license may be renewed or reissued to an applicant holding a valid alcoholic beverage license on December 11, 2001, but only for the same location and class of consumption as is permitted under the then existing alcoholic beverage license. (d) The chairman of the board of commissioners shall have the ability to suspend any license issued under this article: (1) Whenever the license holder or his manager or other employees violate any of the terms of this article. (2) When the license holder, his manager or any other employee shall be charged with the violation of any federal, state or municipal criminal statute or ordinance. (3) For the failure of the license holder to ascertain and require that his managers and employees be and remain qualified to work and manage at the licensed location as contemplated by subsections (b)(1) and (b)(2) of this section. (4) Where the conduct of the license holder's business constitutes a public nuisance or a disorderly house, as defined under state law. (e) In the event of a suspension, the chairman shall report such suspension at the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners, at which time the board shall decide whether to reinstate the license, continue the suspension or revoke the license, upon such terms and conditions as to the board may seem fit and proper. (f) If the board of commissioners continues the suspension of an alcoholic beverage license which authorizes on-premises consumption, or suspends or revokes such a license, the business license of the holder of such alcoholic beverage license authorizing on-premises consumption shall be suspended for a period of six months, which six-month period shall commence to run from the date that the board of commissioners took action to continue the suspension of the alcoholic beverage license, suspend or revoke such license, as the case may be. (g) All decisions approving, denying, suspending, or revoking any alcoholic beverage license shall be in writing, with the reasons therefor stated, and shall be mailed or delivered to the applicant or license holder, as the case may be. (h) Any applicant or license holder, as the case may be, who is aggrieved by the decision of the board of commissioners, shall be afforded a hearing with an opportunity to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses, upon application made within ten days of such decision. Such hearing shall be held at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 301, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-63. - Application; information and agreement therein. Before any license required by this article shall be issued to any person, such person shall file with the county clerk a written application therefor, which application shall have attached thereto a certified check in payment of the initial tax provided for in section 6-31 and which application shall contain the following information and agreement: (1) Full name, address, social security number and birth date of the applicant and the applicant's manager or agent if different from the applicant, and whether the applicant is an individual, partnership or corporation; if the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of each partner must be shown. (2) The location or address of the place or business at which the applicant will engage in the retail malt beverage or wine business, if and when permission to do so is granted by the board of commissioners and a license issued. (3) The application shall also indicate whether the applicant seeks authority to sell malt beverages or wine by the package or for consumption on premises or both, and such application shall also contain such other information as the county clerk may, under the direction of the board of commissioners, from time to time, require. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 302, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-64. - Publication of application. All information contained in the application for the privilege and license to sell malt beverages or wine in the county shall be published in the official newspaper of the county, once a week for four consecutive weeks immediately preceding the week in which the meeting to act upon the application shall be held. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 303, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-65. - Action on application; license issuance. (a) All applications for a license required by this article filed with the board shall be presented to the board of commissioners in a meeting duly assembled and, after investigating the fitness of the applicant and the applicant's manager or agent, if different from the applicant, and the fitness of the proposed location of the retail malt beverage or wine dealership, the board of commissioners shall approve or disapprove the application. (b) In case such application is disapproved, the clerk shall return to the applicant the check submitted with his application. In case such application is approved, the clerk shall issue a proper license to the applicant authorizing the applicant to engage in the business of a retail malt beverage or wine dealer at the business location designated in the application. It shall be indicated on the license whether the application is authority to sell malt beverages or wine by the package or for consumption on premises. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 304, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-66. - Licenses nontransferable; expiration. Licenses required by this article shall be applicable to and valid with respect only to the business location referred to therein, and shall not be transferable to any person other than the named licensee. Such licenses shall expire upon and be of no validity after December 31 next after their issuance. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 305, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-67. - Sale on election days. The sale of alcoholic beverages in the county shall be permitted on election days pursuant to the authority of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20(2)(B) subject to any and all restrictions and limitations contained in this article. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 306, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-68. - Hours of sale. (a) No malt beverages or wine shall be sold by a licensee under this article except during the following hours: 6:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight, Monday through Saturday, and 12:00 midnight to 1:30 a.m. on Saturday. (b) No business establishment in which malt beverages or wines are licensed to be sold under this article for consumption on premises shall remain open between the hours of 12:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., Monday through Friday. No business establishment in which malt beverages or wines are licensed to be sold under this article for consumption on premises shall remain open between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturday. No person, except the license holder or his employee, shall be or remain on the premises of such business establishment during the hours when it is closed. On Sundays, between the hours of 12:30 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, no alcoholic beverage shall be possessed or consumed on the premises of any business establishment in which malt beverages or wines are licensed to be sold under this article for consumption on the premises. (c) The provisions of this section notwithstanding, no malt beverages shall be sold at a time prohibited by state law. (d) Every licensee under this article shall report to the sheriff of the county within the 24 hours thereof each and every incident in which there is a disturbance or breach of the peace or other crime committed on or about the licensed premises. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 307, 12-11-2001) Sec. 6-69. - Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages outside of licensed premises unlawful. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume alcoholic beverages on the premises of a license holder under this article except within the building on such premises as defined and allowed by this chapter. (b) It shall also be unlawful for any person to go upon or remain upon the premises of a license holder except for the purpose of becoming a customer who shall, without delay, enter the building after arriving at the premises and who shall, without delay, leave the premises after exiting such building. (Ord. No. 2001-0019, § 308, 12-11-2001)

div.head: Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30. State Law reference— Dogfighting, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; sale of dog meat for human consumption prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-160; fishing in private ponds, O.C.G.A. § 27-4-30 et seq.; wild animals, O.C.G.A. § 27-5-4 et seq.; Rabies Control, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; animal bites, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4; inoculation of dogs and cats against rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-5; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq.; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to run at large prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7; authority to exercise animal control, Ga. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 14-1—14-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOGS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.
Sec. 14-31. - Definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Board means the animal control board. Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: (1) Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989; or (2) Aggressively bites, attacks, or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. Dog control officer means an individual selected by the county pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22 to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm, or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or control of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the county. Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence, or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. Records of an appropriate authority means records of any state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency; records of any county or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state, or local court; or records of a dog control officer as provided in this article and by the laws of the state. Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. (b) The terms "dangerous dog" and "potentially dangerous dog," as defined in subsection (a) of this section, shall not include the following: (1) A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties; and (2) A dog that inflicts an injury within the meaning of this article if the injury was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, §§ 1, 2) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-32. - Violations; penalties. (a) The owner of a dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-36 or section 14-37 or whose dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 14-38(a) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, for the second conviction a fine or not less than $500.00 shall be imposed and for a third or subsequent conviction a fine of not less than $750.00 shall be imposed. (b) The owner of a potentially dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-36 or section 14-37 or whose potentially dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 14-38(b) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, for a second conviction a fine of not less than $150.00 shall be imposed and for a third or subsequent conviction a fine of not less than $300.00 shall be imposed. (c) If an owner who has a previous conviction for a violation of this article knowingly and willfully fails to comply with the provisions of this article, such owner shall be guilty of a felony if the owner's dangerous dog attacks or bites a human being under circumstances constituting another violation of this article. The owner of a dangerous dog who is convicted for a violation of this subsection shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $5,000.00 or by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than five years or by both such fine and imprisonment as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(c). (d) An owner who knowingly and willfully fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a felony if the owner's dangerous dog aggressively attacks and causes severe injury or death of a human being under circumstances constituting a violation of this article. The owner of a dangerous dog who is convicted of a violation of this subsection shall be punished by a fine of not less than $5,000.00 nor more than $10,000.00 or by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than ten years or by both such fine and imprisonment as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-18(d). (e) In addition to the penalties for violations under subsection (c) or (d) of this section, the dangerous dog involved shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or another person authorized by the dog control officer and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health, and, thereafter, the dangerous dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (f) No owner of a dangerous dog shall be held criminally liable under this article for injuries inflicted by such owner's dog to any human being while on the owner's property. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, § 9) Sec. 14-33. - Animal control board. (a) There is created and established an animal control board. The purpose of the board shall be to conduct the hearings provided for in section 14-35. (b) The board shall consist of five members. All members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners. The initial terms of members shall be as follows: one member to serve for one year, two members to serve for two years, and two members to serve for three years. Thereafter, all members appointed to the board by the board of commissioners shall be appointed for terms of three years and until their successors are appointed. (c) No member of the board shall participate in a hearing on any matter in which such member previously participated in the classification of the dog at issue. In the event of a vacancy during the term of any member by reason of death, resignation, or otherwise, the appointment of a successor by the board of commissioners shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, § 3) Cross reference— Authorities, boards and commissions, § 2-131 et seq. Sec. 14-34. - Dog control officer. The board of commissioners shall appoint a dog control officer who shall serve at the pleasure of the board of commissioners. The dog control officer's compensation shall be established from time to time by the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, § 4) Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Sec. 14-35. - Procedures for classifying dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs; notice; hearing. (a) The dog control officer, upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the county from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer, or county board of health, shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to determine the validity of such report and whether the dog should be classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or reclassified as a dangerous dog if previously classified as a potentially dangerous dog. (b) Should the dog control officer determine that a dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall classify such dog accordingly. The dog control officer shall then notify the dog's owner of such classification. The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements: (1) The notice shall be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address; (2) The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; (3) The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (4) The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the animal control board; (5) The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and (6) The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the animal control board and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the board. (c) When the animal control board receives a request for a hearing as provided in subsection (b) of this section, it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time, and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence. In addition, the board shall receive at the hearing such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. (d) Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the animal control board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, § 5) Sec. 14-36. - Requirements for possessing a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. (a) No one shall have, own, or possess within the county a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration. (b) The dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer or the dog control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of: (1) A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; and (2) The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall receive such sign from the dog control officer at the time the owner pays the annual registration fee as required in subsection (d) of this section. (c) In addition to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the dog control officer evidence of: (1) A policy of insurance in the amount of at least $15,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of the dangerous dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog; or (2) A surety bond in the amount of $15,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in the state payable to any person or persons injured by the dangerous dog. (d) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall pay an annual registration fee at the time the annual certificate of registration is issued. The annual registration fee shall be in the amount of $100.00. Certificates of registration shall be renewed in the month of the initial registration. (e) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the county. (f) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the state shall register such dog as required by this article within 30 days after becoming a resident of the state and the county. (g) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves to the county from any other county within the state shall register such dog as required by this article within ten days after becoming a resident of the county. (h) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, § 6) Sec. 14-37. - Restrictions on permitting dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs outside of a proper enclosure. (a) It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will prevent the dog from biting any person but shall not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration. (b) It shall be unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, § 7) Sec. 14-38. - Confiscation of dogs; grounds; disposition. (a) A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if: (1) The owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or surety bond required by section 14-36(c); (2) The dog is not validly registered as required by this article; (3) The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (4) The dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-37(a). (b) A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if: (1) The dog is not validly registered as required by this article; (2) The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (3) The dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-37(a). (c) Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article as determined by the dog control officer and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs. If the owner has not complied with the provisions of this section within 20 days of the date the dog is confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (Ord. of 2-11-1997, § 8)

Sec. 18-1. - Certificate required for electrical service. It shall be unlawful for the initial installation of electrical service to any building or residence in any unincorporated area of the county unless there shall be obtained first a certificate or statement from the county department of public health that such building or residence has an approved site plan or an approved waste disposal system installed. It shall be deemed unlawful for the initial installation of electrical service for any such building or dwelling without such certificate from the county department of public health. It is the intent of the county to enforce the latest edition of the following state minimum standard codes, as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs: (1) Standard Building Code (2) Standard Fire Prevention Code (3) Standard Gas Code (4) Standard Mechanical Code (5) Standard Plumbing Code (6) National Electrical Code (7) CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code (8) Georgia State Energy Code (Ord. No. 99-019, 10-12-1999) Sec. 18-33. - Adoption by reference.
