Floodway means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. Highest adjacent grade means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface, prior to construction, adjacent to the proposed foundation of a building. Historic structure means any structure that is: (1) Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the U.S. Department of Interior) or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as meeting the requirements for individual listing on the National Register; (2) Certified or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; (3) Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places and determined as eligible by states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the secretary of the interior; or (4) Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places and determined as eligible by communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either: a. By an approved state program as determined by the secretary of the interior; or b. Directly by the secretary of the interior in states without approved programs. Lowest floor means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area, including the basement. An unfinished or flood-resistant enclosure below an elevated building, used solely for parking of vehicles, building access, or minimal storage, in an area other than a basement, is not considered a building's lowest floor; provided, that such enclosure is built so as to not render the structure in violation of any other provision of this article. Manufactured home means a building, transportable in one or more sections, built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. The term "manufactured home" also includes park trailers, travel trailers, and similar transportable structures placed on a site for 180 consecutive days or longer and intended to be improved property. Mean sea level means the average height of the sea for all stages of the tide. It is used as a reference for establishing various elevations within the floodplain. For purposes of this article, the term is synonymous with National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD). National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD), as corrected in 1929, is a vertical control used as a reference for establishing varying elevations within the floodplain. New construction means any structure for which the start of construction commenced after July 1, 1990. New manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed on or after July 1, 1990. Recreational vehicle means a vehicle which is: (1) Built on a single chassis; (2) No more than 400 square feet when measured at the largest horizontal projection; (3) Designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light-duty truck; and (4) Designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use. Start of construction means the date the development permit was issued, provided the actual start of construction, repair, reconstruction, or improvement was within 180 days of the permit date. The actual start means the first placement of permanent construction of a structure on a site, such as the pouring of slabs or footings, installation of piles, construction of columns, or any work beyond the stage of excavation, and includes the placement of a manufactured home on a foundation. Permanent construction does not include initial land preparation, such as clearing, grading and filling; nor does it include the installation of streets and/or walkways; nor does it include excavation for a basement, footings, piers or foundations or the erection of temporary forms; nor does it include the installation on the property of buildings appurtenant to the permitted structure, such as garages or sheds not occupied as dwelling units or not part of the main structure. (NOTE: accessory structures are not exempt from any article requirements). For a substantial improvement, the actual start of construction means the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of a building, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the building. Structure means a walled and roofed building that is principally above the ground, as well as a manufactured home, and a gas or liquid storage tank. Substantial damage means damage of any origin sustained by a structure whereby the cost of restoring the structure to its before damaged condition would equal or exceed 50 percent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. Substantial improvement means any combination of repairs, reconstruction, alteration, or improvements to a building, taking place during a five-year period, in which the cumulative cost equals or exceeds 50 percent of the market value of the structure prior to the improvement. The market value of the building should be the appraised value of the structure prior to the start of the initial repair or improvement, or in the case of damage, the value of the structure prior to the damage occurring. This term includes structures which have incurred substantial damage, regardless of the actual amount of repair work performed. For the purposes of this definition, substantial improvement is considered to occur when the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of the building commences, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the building. The term does not, however, include those improvements of a building required to comply with existing health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which are solely necessary to ensure safe living conditions, which have been preidentified by the building official, and not solely triggered by an improvement or repair project. Substantially improved existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions is where the repair, reconstruction, rehabilitation or improvement of the streets, utilities and pads equals or exceeds 50 percent of the value of the streets, utilities and pads before the repair, reconstruction or improvement commenced. Variance means a grant of relief from the requirements of this article which permits construction in a manner otherwise prohibited by this article. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 6) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 38-32. - Penalties for violation. (a) Violation of the provisions of this article or failure to comply with any of its requirements, including violation of conditions and safeguards established in connection with grants of variance or special exceptions shall constitute a misdemeanor. (b) Any person who violates this article or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-12. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the county from taking such other lawful actions as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § H) Sec. 38-33. - Statutory authorization. The constitution of the state has in article IX, section II, delegated responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 1, § A) Sec. 38-34. - Findings of fact. (a) The flood hazard areas of the county are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood relief and protection, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. (b) Flood losses are caused by the occupancy in flood hazard areas of uses vulnerable to floods, which are inadequately elevated, floodproofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages, and by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 1, § B) Sec. 38-35. - Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: (1) Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction. (2) Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion. (3) Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion. (4) Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands. (5) Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 1, § C) Sec. 38-36. - Objectives. The objectives of this article are to: (1) Protect human life and health; (2) Minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; (3) Help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of floodprone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; (4) Minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; (5) Minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; (6) Minimize prolonged business interruptions; and (7) Promote notification to buyers of property located in a flood hazard area. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 1, § D) Sec. 38-37. - Lands to which this article applies. This article shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the jurisdiction of the county. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § A) Sec. 38-38. - Basis for establishing area of special flood hazard. The areas of special flood hazard are delineated on a flood insurance rate map or flood hazard boundary map, dated July 1, 1990, produced for the community by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). This map, with accompanying technical data and other supporting documentation, and any revision thereto, is adopted by reference and declared a part of this article. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § B) Sec. 38-39. - Compliance with article provisions. No structure or land shall be located, extended, converted or altered without full compliance with the terms of this article and other applicable regulations. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § D) Sec. 38-40. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. This article is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing ordinance, easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this article and another conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § E) Sec. 38-41. - Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of this article, all provisions shall be: (1) Considered as minimum requirements; (2) Liberally construed in favor of the board of commissioners; and (3) Deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § F) Sec. 38-42. - Warning and disclaimer of liability. The degree of flood protection required by this article is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. Larger floods can and will occur, and flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This article does not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazard or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This article shall not create liability on the part of the county or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this article or any administrative decision lawfully made under this article. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § G) Secs. 38-43—38-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
Sec. 38-61. - Designation of floodplain administrator. The building official is appointed as the floodplain administrator to administer and implement the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 3, § A) Sec. 38-62. - Duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator. The duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: (1) Review all development permits to ensure that the permit requirements of this article have been satisfied. (2) Review proposed development to ensure that all necessary permits have been received from governmental agencies from which approval is required by federal or state law, including section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, 33 USC 1334. Require that copies of such permits be provided and maintained on file. (3) When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 38-38, the floodplain administrator shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state or other source, in order to administer the provisions of division 3 of this article. (4) Verify and record the actual elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade if applicable) of the lowest floor, including the basement, of all new or substantially improved structures in accordance with section 38-64(a)(2). (5) Verify and record the actual elevation, in relation to mean sea level to which any new or substantially improved structures have been floodproofed, in accordance with section 38-64(a)(2). (6) When floodproofing is utilized for a structure, the floodplain administrator shall obtain certification of design criteria from a registered professional engineer or architect in accordance with section 38-64(a)(1)c., section 38-92(2) or section 38-94(2). (7) Notify adjacent communities and the state department of natural resources prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (8) Submit engineering data/analysis within six months to FEMA for any altered or relocated watercourse in order to ensure the accuracy of the community's flood data. The community shall ensure the flood-carrying capacity of any altered or relocated watercourse is maintained. (9) Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of boundaries of the areas of special flood hazard (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the floodplain administrator shall make the necessary interpretation. Any person contesting the location of the boundary shall be given a reasonable opportunity to appeal the interpretation as provided in this article. (10) All records pertaining to the provisions of this article shall be maintained in the office of the floodplain administrator and shall be open for public inspection. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 3, § C) Sec. 38-63. - Development permit required. A development permit shall be required prior to the commencement of any development activities in conformance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 2, § C) Sec. 38-64. - Permit procedures. (a) Application. Application for a development permit shall be made to the floodplain administrator on forms furnished by the community prior to any development activity, and may include, but not be limited to, plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the elevations of the area in question and the nature, location, and dimensions of existing or proposed structures, earthen fill placement, storage of materials or equipment, drainage facilities, and topographic alterations. Specifically, the following information is required: (1) Application stage. a. Elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade if applicable) of the lowest floor, including the basement, of all proposed structures. b. Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any nonresidential structure will be floodproofed. c. Design certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that any proposed nonresidential floodproofed structure will meet the floodproofing criteria of sections 38-92(2) and 38-94(2). d. Description of the extent to which any watercourse will be altered or relocated as a result of a proposed development. (3) Construction stage. For all new construction and substantial improvements, the permit holder shall provide to the floodplain administrator an as-built certification of the regulatory lowest floor elevation or floodproofing level immediately after the lowest floor or floodproofing is completed. Any lowest floor certification made relative to mean sea level shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a licensed land surveyor or registered professional engineer and certified by same. When floodproofing is utilized for nonresidential structures, such certification shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a professional engineer or architect and certified by same. (b) Review. The floodplain administrator shall review the certification data submitted as referenced in subsection (a) of this section. Deficiencies detected by such review shall be corrected by the permit holder immediately and prior to further being allowed to proceed. Failure to submit certification or failure to make such corrections required by this section, shall be cause to issue a stop work order for the project. Any work undertaken prior to submission of these certifications shall be at the permit holder's risk. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 3, § B) Sec. 38-65. - Variance procedures. (a) The board of commissioners shall hear and decide all requests for appeals or variance from the requirements of this article. (b) The board shall hear and decide appeals when it is alleged an error in any requirement, decision, or determination is made by the floodplain administrator in the enforcement or administration of this article. (c) Any person aggrieved by the decision of the board of commissioners may appeal such decision to the appropriate court as provided in state statute. (d) Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of historic structures upon a determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as an historic structure and the variance is the minimum to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. (e) Variances may be issued for development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use, provided the criteria of this article are met and no reasonable alternative exists. The development must be protected by methods that minimize flood damage during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. (f) Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. (g) In reviewing such requests, the board of commissioners shall consider all technical evaluations, relevant factors, and all standards specified in this and other sections of this article. (h) Conditions for variances are as follows: (1) Variances shall only be issued when there is a: a. Finding of good and sufficient cause; b. Determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship; and c. Determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisance, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. (i) The provisions of this article are minimum standards for flood loss reduction, therefore any deviation from the standards must be weighed carefully. Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief; and, in the instance of an historic structure, a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary so as not to destroy the historic character and design of the building. (j) Any applicant to whom a variance is granted shall be given written notice specifying the difference between the base flood elevation and the elevation of the proposed lowest floor and stating that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk to life and property resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. (k) The floodplain administrator shall maintain the records of all appeal actions and report any variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. (l) Upon consideration of the factors listed in this section and the purposes of this article, the board of commissioners may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purposes of this article. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 5) Secs. 38-66—38-90. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - FLOOD HAZARD REDUCTION
Sec. 38-91. - General standards. In all areas of special flood hazard, the following provisions are required: (1) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure. (2) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage. (3) New construction or substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage. (4) In elevated buildings, all new construction or substantial improvements of existing structures that include any fully enclosed area located below the elevated building's lowest floor formed by foundation and other exterior walls, shall be designed to be an unfinished or flood-resistant enclosure. The enclosure shall also be designed to equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the automatic entry and exit of floodwater. a. Designs for complying with the automatic equalization requirement must either be certified by a professional engineer or architect or meet the following minimum criteria: 1. Provide a minimum of two openings having a total net area of not less than one square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding; 2. The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one foot above grade; and 3. Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices provided they permit the automatic flow of floodwater in both directions. b. So as not to violate the lowest floor criteria of this article, the unfinished or flood-resistant enclosure shall only be used for parking of vehicles, limited storage of maintenance equipment used in connection with the premises, or entry to the elevated area. c. The interior portion of the enclosed area shall not be partitioned or finished into separate rooms. (5) All heating and air conditioning equipment and components, all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding. (6) Manufactured homes shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This standard shall be in addition to and consistent with applicable state requirements for resisting wind forces. (7) New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the system. (8) New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters. (9) On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. (10) Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvement to a structure which is not compliant with the provisions of this article shall be undertaken only if the nonconformity is not furthered, extended or replaced. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 4, § A) Sec. 38-92. - Specific standards. In all areas of special flood hazard where base flood elevation data are available, the following provisions are required: (1) New construction and substantial improvements. New construction or the substantial improvement of any structure or manufactured home shall have the lowest floor, including the basement, elevated no lower than one foot above the base flood elevation. Should solid foundation perimeter walls be used to elevate a structure, openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with the standards of section 38-91(4). (2) Nonresidential construction. New construction or the substantial improvement of any nonresidential structure located in A1-30, AE, or AH zones, may be floodproofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be watertight to one foot above the base flood elevation, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and in section 38-62(6). (3) Manufactured homes and recreational vehicles. Where base flood elevation data are available: a. All manufactured homes placed or substantially improved on individual lots or parcels, in new or substantially improved manufactured home parks or subdivisions, in expansions to existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions, or on a site in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision where a manufactured home has incurred substantial damage as the result of a flood, must have the lowest floor, including the basement, elevated no lower than one foot above the base flood elevation. b. Manufactured homes placed or substantially improved in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision may be elevated so that either: 1. The lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated no lower than one foot above the level of the base flood elevation; or 2. The manufactured home chassis is elevated and supported by reinforced piers (or other foundation elements of at least an equivalent strength) no less than 36 inches in height above grade. c. All manufactured homes must be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement. d. All recreational vehicles placed on site must: 1. Be fully licensed and ready for highway use. 2. Meet all the requirements for new construction, including the anchoring and elevation requirements of subsections (3)a. and (3)c. of this section. A recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is licensed, on its wheels or jacking system, attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached structures or additions. (4) Floodway. Within areas of special flood hazard, established in section 38-38, a designated floodway may exist. A floodway may be an extremely hazardous area due to velocity floodwaters, debris or erosion potential. A floodway must remain free of new encroachment in order to allow for the discharge of a base flood without increased flood heights. Therefore, the following provisions shall apply: a. Floodway encroachments are prohibited, including earthen fill, new construction, substantial improvements or other development within the regulatory floodway. An encroachment may be permitted however, provided it is demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the encroachment shall not result in any increase in flood levels or floodway widths during a base flood discharge. A registered professional engineer must provide supporting technical data and certification thereof. b. Only if subsection (4)a. of this section is satisfied, then any new construction or substantial improvement shall comply with all other applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of this division. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 4, § B) Sec. 38-93. - Standards for streams without established base flood elevations and/or floodway (A zones). Located within the areas of special flood hazard, established in section 38-38, where streams exist but no base flood data have been provided (A zones), or where base flood data have been provided but a floodway has not been delineated, the following provisions apply: (1) When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 38-38, then the floodplain administrator shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize any scientific or historic base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state, or other source, in order to administer the provisions of this division. Only if data are not available from these sources, then the provisions of subsections (2) and (3) of this section shall apply. (2) No encroachments, including structures or fill material, shall be located within an area equal to the width of the stream or 25 feet, whichever is greater, measured from the top of the stream bank, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that such encroachment shall not result in any increase in flood levels during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. (3) In special flood hazard areas without base flood elevation data, new construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall have the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including the basement) elevated no less than three feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with the standards of section 38-91(4). The administrator shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 4, § C) Sec. 38-94. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO zones). Areas of special flood hazard, established in section 38-38, may include designated AO shallow flooding areas. These areas have base flood depths of one foot to three feet above the ground, with no clearly defined channel. The following provisions apply: (1) All new construction and substantial improvements of residential and nonresidential structures shall have the lowest floor, including the basement, elevated to the flood depth number specified on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM) above the highest adjacent grade. If no flood depth number is specified, the lowest floor, including the basement, shall be elevated at least three feet above the highest adjacent grade. Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with the standards of section 38-91(4). The floodplain administrator shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (2) New construction or the substantial improvement of a nonresidential structure may be floodproofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be watertight to the specified FIRM flood level plus one foot, above the highest adjacent grade, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and as required in section 38-64. (3) Drainage paths shall be provided to guide floodwater around and away from any proposed structure. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 4, § D) Sec. 38-95. - Standards for subdivision proposals. The standards for subdivision proposals are as follows: (1) All subdivision proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; (2) All subdivision proposals shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage; (3) All subdivision proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards; and (4) Base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision proposals and all other proposed development, including manufactured home parks and subdivisions, greater than 50 lots or five acres, whichever is less. (Ord. of 5-13-1997, art. 4, § E)

div.head: Chapter 42 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 26; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 46; traffic and vehicles, ch. 74. State Law reference— Law enforcement officer appreciation day, O.C.G.A. § 1-4-6; peace officer memorial day and police week, O.C.G.A. § 1-4-7; Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; training requirements for police chiefs, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-20; special police, O.C.G.A. § 35-9-1 et seq.; municipality's liability for torts of police or other officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-3; definition of police officer for purpose of state traffic laws, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1(46); fleeing or attempting to elude police officers, impersonating law enforcement officer, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-395; public officer causing arrest or detention for violation of O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1 not civilly liable, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1(d); assault under color of office, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-3; extortion generally, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-5; tort liability for false arrest, O.C.G.A. § 51-7-1 et seq.; tort liability for false imprisonment, O.C.G.A. § 51-7-20 et seq.; tort liability for malicious prosecution, O.C.G.A. § 51-7-40; authority to provide police and fire protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 42-1—42-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COUNTY POLICE DEPARTMENT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— County police, O.C.G.A. § 36-8-1 et seq.
Sec. 42-31. - Established. Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-8-1 et seq., a county law enforcement agency to be known as the Mitchell County Police Department is established. (Ord. of 5-14-1991, § 1) Sec. 42-32. - Appointment of police officer; duties. Initially, the department shall consist of one police officer who shall be appointed by the board of commissioners after receiving recommendations from the executive committee of the Mitchell County Drug Squad. His primary duties will be to act as commander of the drug unit and as such to enforce all the laws against the use, possession, sale and distribution of illegal drugs within his jurisdiction and to cooperate with local, state and federal agencies to eradicate the drug problem in the county. The commander shall be entitled to hire another county police officer to act as investigator for the drug unit. (Ord. of 5-14-1991, § 2) Sec. 42-33. - Additional responsibilities of department. The board of commissioners shall be authorized to expand the activities of the Mitchell County Police Department as the law enforcement needs of the county dictate and to increase the number of police officers to handle the department's additional responsibilities. (Ord. of 5-14-1991, § 3) Sec. 42-34. - Rules and regulations. The county police department shall be subject to such rules and regulations for the conduct and management of its affairs as the board of commissioners shall adopt and from time to time in its discretion enlarge, modify or change. Furthermore, county police officers shall have the same powers to make arrests and to execute and return criminal warrants and processes as the sheriff of the county has, and shall also have all powers of a sheriff as a peace officer within the county. (Ord. of 5-14-1991, § 4) Sec. 42-35. - Direction and supervision. Any indication in this article to the contrary notwithstanding county police officers will nonetheless be employees of the county under the direction and supervision of the county administrator and subject to the same terms and conditions of employment as other employees of the county. (Ord. of 5-14-1991, § 5) Sec. 42-36. - Bond. All police officers shall be required to enter into a good and solvent bond in an amount to be set by the board of commissioners, conditioned for the faithful performance of all their duties. (Ord. of 5-14-1991, § 6) Sec. 42-37. - County drug unit policy and procedures manual. The Mitchell County Drug Unit Policy and Procedures Manual, which is incorporated by reference and made a part of this article, is officially adopted as a part of the rules and regulations for the conduct, management and control of the Mitchell County Police Force. (Ord. of 10-8-1991) Sec. 42-38. - Provisions incorporated by reference. The provisions of the manual referred to in section 42-37 relating to personnel practices and procedures shall be cumulative of the County Personnel and Procedures Manual. In the event of a conflict in the provisions of the two manuals or in the interpretation thereof, the county manual shall take precedent over the drug unit manual, which shall, in all respects, be subordinate to the county manual. (Ord. of 10-8-1991)

div.head: Chapter 46 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Law enforcement, ch. 42; traffic and vehicles, ch. 74. State Law reference— Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 46-1—46-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADDITIONAL PENALTIES
Sec. 46-31. - Jail Construction and Staffing Act. The board of commissioners places into effect O.C.G.A. § 15-21-90 et seq., known as the Jail Construction and Staffing Act. (Ord. of 11-13-1990, § 1) Sec. 46-32. - Imposition. (a) (1) In every case in which the Superior Court of Mitchell County, State Court of Mitchell County, Probate Court of Mitchell County or Magistrate Court of Mitchell County shall impose a fine, which shall be construed to include costs, for any offense against a criminal or traffic law of the state or any provision of this Code, there shall be imposed as an additional penalty a sum equal to ten percent of the original fine. (2) At the time of posting bail or bond in any case involving a violation of a criminal or traffic law of the state or ordinance of the county, an additional sum equal to ten percent of the original amount of the bail or bond shall be posted. In every case in which the Superior Court of Mitchell County, State Court of Mitchell County, Probate Court of Mitchell County, or Magistrate Court of Mitchell County shall order the forfeiture of bail or bond, the additional sum equal to ten percent of the original bail or bond shall be paid over as provided in section 46-33. (b) Sums required by subsection (a) of this section shall be in addition to that amount required by O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 to be paid into the peace officers annuity and benefit fund or O.C.G.A. § 47-11-51 concerning the judges of the probate court's retirement fund of the state. (Ord. of 11-13-1990, § 2) Sec. 46-33. - Collection. (a) The sums provided for in section 46-32 shall be assessed and collected by the clerk or court officer charged with the duty of collecting monies arising from fines and forfeited bonds and shall be paid over to the board of commissioners of the county by the tenth day of the month following the month in which such sums are collected. Such sums paid over to the board of commissioners shall be deposited by the board of commissioners into a special account to be known as the county jail fund. (b) Any person whose duty it is to collect and remit the sums provided for in section 46-32 who fails and refuses to remit such sums by the date required by this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided by law. (Ord. of 11-13-1990, § 3) Sec. 46-34. - Use of monies collected. Monies collected pursuant to this article and placed in the county jail fund shall be expended by the board of commissioners of the county, solely and exclusively for constructing, operating, and staffing county jails, county correctional institutions and detention facilities of the county, or for the purpose of contracting for such facilities with other counties, the state, municipalities or other political subdivisions as authorized by Ga. Const. art. IX, § III, ¶ I. The county jail fund and monies collected pursuant to this article to be placed in the county jail fund may be pledged as security for the payment of bonds issued for the construction of county jails, county correctional institutions and detention facilities of the county, or such other counties with whom it may have contracted. (Ord. of 11-13-1990, § 4)

div.head: Chapter 50 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30. State Law reference— State parks, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-1 et seq.; establishment of recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.; Georgia State Games Commission, O.C.G.A. § 50-12-40 et seq.; authority to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 50-1—50-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Recreation boards, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-5.
Sec. 50-31. - Created. The Mitchell County Parks and Recreation Department, referred to as the "department" in this article, is created and established by and between the following entities, referred to as the "parties" in this article: the cities of Baconton, Camilla, Pelham, and Sale City, referred to as the "cities" in this article; the Mitchell County Board of Education, referred to as the "board" in this article; the City of Pelham Board of Education, referred to as the "Pelham Board" in this article; and Mitchell County, referred to as the "county" in this article; as provided in O.C.G.A. ch. 36-64 (recreation systems); and such department shall be organized and empowered as set out in this article. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-1, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-32. - Commission created. The Mitchell County Parks and Recreation Commission, referred to as the commission in this article, is created and established by and between the parties as provided in O.C.G.A. ch. 36-64 (recreation systems); and shall be organized and empowered as set out in this article. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-2, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-33. - Appointment of members; terms; vacancy; removal. (a) The commission, when established, shall consist of seven appointed members, serving without pay, to be appointed by the governing authorities, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1, of each of the parties as provided below. The terms of office of the members of the commission shall be for five years or until their successors are appointed and qualified. Each member may be reappointed, but for no more than two consecutive terms. (b) In order that the term of at least one member shall expire annually, the original appointments shall be made by the parties as follows: (1) The County of Mitchell, by and through its board of commissioners, shall appoint one member for a five-year term; (2) The City of Camilla, by and through its mayor and council, shall appoint one member for a four-year term; (3) The City of Pelham, by and through its mayor and council, shall appoint one member for a three-year term; (4) The City of Sale City, by and through its mayor and council, shall appoint one member for a two-year term; (5) The City of Baconton, by and through its mayor and council, shall appoint one member for a one-year term; (6) The Pelham Board of Education shall appoint one member for a one-year term; and (7) The Mitchell County Board of Education shall appoint one member for a one-year term. Upon the expiration of each of the initial terms, each of the parties shall appoint one replacement member in the same manner as the original appointments were made, for a five-year term. (c) All members of the commission may be reimbursed for actual expense incurred in connection with their official duties. (d) Each governing body shall have complete authority to remove its appointed member of the commission. (e) Any vacancy on the commission shall be filled only for the unexpired term by the governing body whose appointee vacates the position. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-3, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-34. - Purpose and responsibility. (a) The purpose of the commission is to carry on a parks and recreation program for the citizens of the county without duplication of services and expense and with fairness and equity to all political subdivisions. The commission shall provide for the continual improvement of programs, facilities, and lands while consistently maintaining the existing facilities in an attractive, safe, and functional condition. (b) The commission shall ensure that the parks and recreation system is administered and operated in the best interests of all citizens of the county and that any funds appropriated for the department by the cities, the board, the Pelham Board, and the county are expended in an effective and efficient manner. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-4, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-35. - Organization and rules. (a) The commission shall elect its chairman and such other officers as are necessary from among its appointed members. The terms of the chairman and such other officers shall be one year or until their successors are duly elected and qualified. (b) The commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of one of the governing bodies, of the commission, or of the department. The secretary shall keep minutes of the meetings and perform such other functions as may be required. (c) The commission shall make its own rules of procedure which are consistent with the law of the state and with the authority granted it by this article, the resolutions of the parties, the ordinances of the cities, and the agreement between the cities, the board, the Pelham Board, and the county. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-5, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-36. - Powers and duties; budget, fees. (a) The commission shall be vested, except as restricted in this article, with all powers and duties as provided for in O.C.G.A. §§ 34-64-3, 36-64-5, 36-64-6, 36-64-9, and 36-64-11 as they now exist or may hereafter be amended. (b) The commission shall, each year, submit in a timely manner to the governing bodies of the parties, a budget for the administration, operation, and maintenance of the parks and recreation system which shows expected expenditures in each of the areas for which the department is responsible. In addition, a five-year capital improvements budget shall be presented annually. The budgets shall continue to be presented, as provided in this subsection, to all of the governing bodies of the parties after the county assumes full responsibility for the department's annual appropriations. (c) The commission is empowered to establish, revise, and collect fees and rentals for the use of recreation areas and to impose conditions and set requirements governing such use. Accurate records of such fees shall always be maintained and open to inspection by all of the governing bodies of the parties. Anticipated fees shall be accounted for in the annual budget. (d) The commission shall periodically report to the governing bodies of the parties the condition of the respective lands and capital improvements thereof and shall immediately notify them of any damage thereto or condition requiring repair and make recommendations concerning such condition and/or required repairs. (e) Nothing in this section shall prevent the commission from contracting with any of the parties to perform work in the recreation areas, but such performance by any of these parties shall be the subject of separate charge and shall not be considered participation by them. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-6, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-37. - Recreation director and other employees; duties. (a) The commission shall appoint a parks and recreation director and such other staff and employees as it may deem necessary to properly and adequately administer the department, but the salaries thereof shall be within and consistent with the budget established and approved. (b) The duties of the parks and recreation director shall be to plan, organize, direct, and control a countrywide recreation program pursuant to the policy established within the budget submitted to and approved by the governing bodies of the parties. The director shall prepare and present to the commission a suggested budget showing anticipated revenues and required expenditures. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-7, 11-13-2001) Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Sec. 50-38. - Financial participation, retention of title to land, and capital improvements; diminishing yearly contributions by the cities, the board, and the Pelham Board. (a) The cities, the board, the Pelham Board, and the county shall, and do respectively, retain title to all their respective lands and capital improvements connected with and used in and by the department, and the commission shall protect and maintain such properties. Further capital investment shall be made with respect to such property by the political subdivision having title thereto. (b) The financial participation of the cities and the county in the initial year of the department shall be determined by written agreement of the cities and the county, which written agreement shall further provide that in succeeding years, after the initial year of the department's operation, the contributions by the cities shall be reduced each year, for a period of five years, after which the county will assume responsibility for the full operating budget of the department. Such written agreement shall be entered into no later than March 30, 2002. For the sixth and succeeding years, the county shall finance the entire budget of the department, and the cities shall not be required to contribute, provided that, in no event, shall the rights of the cities and their residents be abridged in any manner in the operation of the department. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-8, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-39. - Contract. The mayors and councils of the cities, the chairpersons of the board and the Pelham Board, and the chair of the county board of commissioners are authorized to enter into and sign a contract to cooperate in the establishment of the department, to provide for the financial participation of the parties in the department, to provide for a term, to provide for termination and arbitration, to provide for assurance that the integrity of the present recreation systems of the cities shall be maintained, and to contain such other terms as may be necessary to carry out the intention of the parties. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-9, 11-13-2001) Sec. 50-40. - Title to capital improvements and lands. The title to capital improvements and lands connected with the delivery of park and recreation services by the commission will remain in the respective governmental subdivisions, but the duty of the commission shall be to administer, operate and maintain such land and capital improvements and to provide a proper parks and recreation program for all of the citizens, with each governing body being responsible for capital improvements to its respective properties. (Ord. No. 2001-017, § 1-10, 11-13-2001)

div.head: Chapter 54 - PLANNING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; roads and bridges, ch. 58; subdivisions, ch. 66; zoning, app. A. State Law reference— Regional development centers, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-30 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 54-1—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING POLICY[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Zoning, app. A. State Law reference— The Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 54-31. - Purpose. The county zoning ordinance will regulate the location and height of buildings and structures; the density of population; the size of yards and other open spaces; the use of land, buildings and structures for industry, commerce, agriculture, recreation, residence public activities and other purposes; create districts for such purposes and establish boundaries; define terms; methods for administration, amendment and enforcement as well as penalties for violating; and provides for zoning appeals. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Sec. 54-32. - Zoning districts. The unincorporated areas of the county are divided into nine zoning districts designated as follows: (1) SFR-I, single-family residential I (2) SFR-II, single-family residential II (3) MFR, multifamily residential (4) AG, residential, forest and agriculture (5) MHP, manufactured home park (6) MHS, manufactured home subdivisions (7) C, commercial (8) I, industrial (9) FH, flood hazard district (10) PUD, planned unit development (Policy of 9-15-1995) Secs. 54-33—54-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR CALLING AND CONDUCTING ZONING HEARINGS
Sec. 54-51. - Petition for rezoning. A property owner, the planning commission, or the board of commissioners may petition for rezoning. An application shall be submitted to the county clerk and the appropriate fee shall be paid. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Sec. 54-52. - Notice of rezoning petition. The county shall place legal notices in the newspaper of general circulation within the county of the rezoning petition at least 15 days but not more than 45 days prior to the required public hearings on the rezoning proposal. Also, a public notice sign shall be placed on the subject property. The notice will state the time, place and purpose of the hearing. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Sec. 54-53. - Public hearing. The county planning commission shall hold a public hearing on a rezoning petition and make recommendations to the board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall hold a public hearing on a rezoning proposal and make a final decision on the rezoning request. If the zoning application is denied by the board of commissioners, reapplication for rezoning may not be heard for 12 months from the date of the initial denial. A rezoning case can be contested in the superior court within 30 days of the zoning decision. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Secs. 54-54—54-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - HEARINGS BEFORE THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 54-71. - Sign up required for hearing. All persons who wish to address the board of commissioners at a hearing on a proposed zoning decision under consideration by the board of commissioners shall first sign up on a form to be provided by the county prior to the commencement of the hearing. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Sec. 54-72. - Hearing procedures. (a) The board of commissioners or its designee will read a proposed zoning decision under consideration and the departmental reviews pertaining thereto prior to receiving public input on such proposed zoning decision. Proposed zoning decisions shall be called in the order in which they were filed. (b) The board of commissioners or its designee shall call each person who has signed up to speak on the zoning decision before the board of commissioners in the order in which the persons have signed up to speak, except that the applicant shall speak first. Prior to speaking, the speaker will identify himself and state his current address. Only those persons who signed up to speak prior to the commencement of the hearings shall be entitled to speak unless two-thirds of the members of the board of commissioners present at the hearing allow the person to speak to the zoning decision. (c) Each speaker shall be allowed five minutes to address the board of commissioners concerning the zoning decision under consideration, unless the board of commissioners, by two-thirds vote of the reading of the proposed zoning decision, vote to allow additional time in which to address the board of commissioners on such proposed zoning decision. The speaker may initially use all of the time allocated to him to speak or he may speak and reserve a portion of his allotted time for rebuttal. One member of the board of commissioners shall be designated as the timekeeper to record the time expended by each speaker. (d) Each speaker shall speak only to the merits of the proposed zoning decision under consideration and shall address his remarks only to the members of the board of commissioners. Each speaker shall refrain from personal attacks on any other speaker or from discussing facts or opinions irrelevant to the proposed zoning decision under consideration. The chair may limit or refuse a speaker the right to continue, if the speaker, after first being cautioned, continues to violate this subsection. (e) Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the chair from conducting the hearing in an orderly and decorous manner to ensure that the public hearing on a proposed zoning decision is conducted in a fair and orderly manner. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Secs. 54-73—54-90. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - HEARINGS BEFORE THE PLANNING COMMISSION
Sec. 54-91. - Sign up required for hearing. All persons who wish to address the planning commission at a zoning hearing under consideration by the planning commission shall first sign up on a form to be provided by the planning commission prior to the commencement of the hearing. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Sec. 54-92. - Hearing procedures. (a) The secretary or chairperson will read the proposed zoning under consideration, and the departmental reviews pertaining thereto, if any, prior to receiving public input on the proposed zoning. Speakers shall be called in the order in which they were filed. (b) The secretary or chairperson of the planning commission shall then call each person who has signed up to speak before the planning commission in the order in which the persons have signed up to speak, except that the applicant shall speak first. Prior to speaking, the speaker will identify himself and state his current address. Only those persons who signed up to speak prior to the commencement of the hearing shall be entitled to speak, unless two-thirds of the members of the planning commission present at the hearing allow the person to speak to the appeal. (c) Each speaker shall speak only to the merits of the proposed zoning under consideration and shall address his remarks only to the members of the planning board. Each speaker shall refrain from personal attacks on any other speaker or from discussing facts or opinions irrelevant to the proposed zoning under consideration. The chair may limit or refuse a speaker the right to continue, if the speaker, after first being cautioned, continues to violate this subsection. (d) Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the chair from conducting the hearing in an orderly and decorous manner to ensure that the public hearing on the zoning is conducted in a fair and orderly manner. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Secs. 54-93—54-110. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - ZONING STANDARDS
Sec. 54-111. - Findings. The county planning commission and the board of commissioners find that the following standards are relevant in balancing the public interest in promoting the public health, safety or general welfare against the right of the property owner to use his property: (1) Does the proposed zoning classification promote the health, safety, morals or general welfare of the county? (2) The existing uses of the subject property and adjacent and near properties. (3) The current zoning of the subject property and adjacent or near properties. (4) The extent to which property values are diminished by the present zoning restriction. (5) The extent to which the restrictions diminishing the property's values promotes the health, safety, morals or general welfare of the public. (6) The relative gain to the public compared to the extent of hardship imposed upon the individual property owner (in retaining the current zoning designation). (7) The suitability of the subject property for the zoned purposes. (8) The history of the use of the subject property considered in the context of land developments in the vicinity of the property. (9) Conformity with the county comprehensive plan. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Sec. 54-112. - Planning commission responsibility; members. The primary purpose of the county planning commission is to research, review, and make recommendations to the board of commissioners on rezoning applications, special exception requests, zoning ordinance amendments and general planning. The county planning commission consists of members from each voting district in the county appointed by the board of commissioners and regular meetings are held the third Thursday of each month. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Sec. 54-113. - Zoning administrator. The zoning administrator shall administer and enforce the zoning ordinance (appendix A to this Code) and is given the authority and responsibility to enforce all provisions of the ordinance under the directions of the board of commissioners. (Policy of 9-15-1995) Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Secs. 54-114—54-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
Sec. 54-131. - Findings. The county commissioners have found it necessary to prepare an amendment to the county comprehensive development plan to address the protective criteria established in the Georgia Mountain and River Corridor Protection Act and where such amendment stipulates that the state department of natural resources criteria for the protection of designated river and creek corridors will be incorporated in the county's land use regulations during the five-year work program. The amendment to the county comprehensive development plan which addresses the adoption of the Mountain and River Corridor Protection Act criteria as reviewed and approved by the Southwest Georgia Regional Development Center and the state department of community affairs shall be adopted. The board of commissioners certify that adequate citizen participation requirements have been met. (Ord. of 12-29-1993) Sec. 54-132. - Short-term work program. The 1998—2002 fiscal year short-term work program of the 1993 county comprehensive plan shall be amended to provide for the support of seeking better hometown status and activities of such if designated for the City of Camilla, Georgia, and the City of Pelham, Georgia. (Res. No. 2001-34-A, 10-9-2001) Secs. 54-133—54-160. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PLANNING COMMISSION[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Authorities, boards and commissions, § 2-131 et seq. State Law reference— Conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; code of ethics for members of boards, commissions and authorities, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-3.
Sec. 54-161. - Established. The board of commissioners establishes the Mitchell County Planning Commission to be governed by the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 6-8-1982) Sec. 54-162. - Membership. The Mitchell County Planning Commission shall consist of five members, one each from the five commission districts. These members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners and shall be residents of the county. (Ord. of 6-8-1982, § 1) Sec. 54-163. - Term of office. The terms of the members of the Mitchell County Planning Commission shall be for five years, except in the appointment of the first Mitchell County Planning Commission. Initial terms shall be for one year, two years, three years, four years, and five years. Any vacancy in the appointed membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the board of commissioners which shall also have the authority to remove any appointed member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All appointed members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Ord. of 6-8-1982, § 2) Sec. 54-164. - Organization, rules and staff. The Mitchell County Planning Commission shall elect its chairman and vice-chairman from among its members. The term of chairman and vice-chairman shall be for one year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the county. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission shall be open to the public and all records of planning commission meetings shall be made public. The planning commission, by and with the consent of the board of commissioners, may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its works, and any contract with consultants for such services as it may require. However, no contract calling for the expenditure of any funds shall be entered into by the planning commission without the express consent of the county commission. The planning commission shall in no event incur any liability that will exceed the amounts appropriated for that purpose by the county. (Ord. of 6-8-1982, § 3) Sec. 54-165. - Powers and duties. From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers, and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then the planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957, as amended. (Ord. of 6-8-1982, § 4) Secs. 54-166—54-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RESOLUTION OF INTER-GOVERNMENTAL LAND USE CLASSIFICATION DISPUTES
Sec. 54-201. - Process for resolving. The following process for resolving land use disputes shall be implemented: (1) Prior to initiating any formal annexation activities, the municipality will notify the county of a proposed annexation and provide information on location of property, size of area, and proposed land use or zoning classification(s) (if applicable) of the property. Within 30 days following receipt of this information, the county will forward to the city a statement either: a. Indicating that the county has no objection to the proposed land use for the property; or b. Describing its bona fide objection(s) to the city's proposed land use classification, providing supporting evidence, and listing any possible stipulations or conditions that would alleviate the county's objection(s). (2) If the county has no objection to the city's proposed land use or zoning classification, the city is free to proceed with the annexation. If the county fails to respond to the city's notice in writing within the deadline, the city is free to proceed with the annexation and the county loses its right to invoke the dispute resolution process, or object to land use changes after the annexation. (3) If the county notifies the city that it has a bona fide land use classification objection(s), the city will respond to the county in writing within 30 days of receiving the county's objection(s) by either: a. Agreeing to implement the county's stipulations and conditions and thereby resolve the county's objection(s). b. Agreeing with the county and stopping action on the proposed annexation. c. Disagreeing that the county's objection(s) are bona fide, the city will initiate a joint meeting of the respective governments to resolve the issue(s). (4) If the city initiates mediation, the city and county will agree on a mediator, mediation schedule and determine participants in the mediation. The city and county agree to share equally any costs associated with the mediation. (5) An annexation proposal shall not be effective until any bona fide land use classification objections raised by the county are resolved pursuant to this section. (6) The final resolution of any recommendation of a land use classification will be accorded to the board of commissioners considering the annexation. In cases of land use disputes not related to annexation proposals, the final resolution of a land use dispute will be accorded to the jurisdiction in which the subject property is located. Notwithstanding, a government may seek declaratory judgment in a court of proper jurisdiction pursuant to a land use decision. (Ord. of 5-12-1998, § 1)

div.head: Chapter 58 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; floods, ch. 38; planning, ch. 54; subdivisions, ch. 66. State Law reference— Probate court's jurisdiction involving the removal of obstructions from roads, O.C.G.A. § 15-9-30.1; obstructing sidewalks or other public passages, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43; damaging, injuring or interfering with utilities, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; Georgia Code of Public Transportation, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-1 et seq.; governmental authorization for construction or maintenance of any private road unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-8; state, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; county road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-40 et seq.; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; state grants for construction and maintenance of county roads, O.C.G.A. § 36-17-20 et seq.; inspection of and reports on roads and bridges by county police, O.C.G.A. § 36-8-6; authority to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 58-1—58-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ROAD NAMES AND ADDRESSES
Sec. 58-31. - Violations. If the owner or occupant of, or other person responsible for, a house or building neglects or refuses to comply with the terms of this article, an official notice shall be served to the owner, occupant, or such other person, at the address. The owner, occupant or other person shall have ten days to bring the property into compliance after which the owner, occupant or other person responsible for such house or building shall be charged with violation of this article, and, if convicted, may be punished as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. No. 2001-018, § 4, 12-11-2001) Sec. 58-32. - Enforcement. The responsibility for making inspections provided in this article, and for the enforcement of the provisions of this article, shall rest upon the sheriff of the county. (Ord. No. 2001-018, § 5, 12-11-2001) Sec. 58-33. - Assignment of road names, requests for names or changes. (a) All existing and/or new public roads and/or streets within the unincorporated boundaries of the county shall be assigned a name approved by the board of commissioners as set forth by the county subdivision regulations. (b) All requests for road and/or street names and/or changes shall be submitted to the county planning commission and forwarded to the board of commissioners for their review and approval. All requests for road names and/or street names shall conform to the requirements of the county subdivision regulations. (Ord. No. 2001-018, § 1, 12-11-2001) Sec. 58-34. - Designation of road and/or street numbers. (a) Road and/or street numbers for each dwelling and place of business on all public and private roads shall be assigned by the building official of the county or his designee in accordance with the uniform system of numbering structures in effect within the county. (b) The building official, in conjunction with the county 911 system, shall keep a record of all numbers that are assigned under this article. (c) No building or structure for which a house number is required shall be occupied prior to the assignment and display of such number and numbers shall be affixed in the proper manner prior to electricity being connected to the building. (d) All persons requiring a house number assignment prior to the occupancy must apply for such number at least three working days in advance of occupancy. (Ord. No. 2001-018, § 2, 12-11-2001) Sec. 58-35. - Posting of designated road and/or street addresses. (a) The owner or occupant of, or other person responsible for, any house or building to which a number has been assigned shall be notified by the county building official or his designee. (b) Within seven days after the receipt of such notification, the owner or occupant of, or other person responsible for, a house or building to which a number has been assigned shall affix the number in a conspicuous place as set forth in subsection (d) of this section. (c) It shall be the responsibility of each owner or occupant of, or other person responsible for, a house or building to remove any different number which might be mistaken for, or confused with, the number assigned to such structure by the building official or his designee. (d) It shall be the responsibility of each owner or occupant of, or other person responsible for, a house or building to which a number has been assigned to display such number in figures at least 2½ inches high and in such a manner that such figures are readable, at the following locations: (1) The number shall be posted on the house or building, at its main entrance or such other place as will render it visible from the right-of-way, driveway or other usual means of approaching the house or building from the closest public road, and in such manner that the numbers are readable from 100 feet; and (2) If the property receives rural mail delivery, the number shall posted on the mailbox; or if the property does not receive rural mail delivery, the number shall be posted at the entrance of the driveway from the right-of-way. However, if the house or building is located less than 100 feet from the public right-of-way and if the number is clearly readable from such public right-of-way, then the number need only be posted on the house or building in accordance with subsection (d)(1) of this section. (Ord. No. 2001-018, § 3, 12-11-2001) Secs. 58-36—58-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TIMBER OPERATIONS
Sec. 58-71. - Violations. Violations of this article are punishable as provided in section 1-12. Prosecutions for violations of this article shall be upon citation as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63 or upon accusation by the county attorney or such other attorney as the board shall designate. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, §§ 7, 8) Sec. 58-72. - Cash bond required. Prior to beginning a tree harvesting operation in the county, all loggers shall post a cash bond in the amount set from time to time by the board of commissioners with the clerk of the board for each and every separate tract of land from which trees are to be removed. For each such tract, the logger shall also provide: (1) His name, address and telephone number. (2) The name, address and telephone number of the foreman on each tract. (3) The name, address and telephone number of the owner of each tract. (4) The approximate location of the site and the county roads that will be used to get to the site. (5) The route that will be used to haul trees from the site to the nearest state route. (6) The anticipated date for the commencement of the removal of trees for each tract. (7) The anticipated date for the completion of the removal of trees for each tract. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 1) Sec. 58-73. - Culverts. Upon receipt of the information required by section 58-72, the county road superintendent shall inspect each site of a tree harvesting operation to determine if a culvert is required to provide ingress and egress from the county road to the tract and, if so, the length and diameter of the culvert. Should a convert be required, it shall be installed at the expense of the logger under the supervision of the road superintendent. Loggers shall have the right to remove any culvert installed upon completion of tree removal. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 2) Sec. 58-74. - Duties of loggers. During the removal of trees from the tract of a tree harvesting operation, the logger shall: (1) Conduct all loading of logs at a site off the county right-of-way and behind the established ditch line maintained by the county. (2) Refrain from loading or skidding any logs upon or across the county's right-of-way. (3) Keep ditches clear of debris and residue so as to not interfere with proper drainage. (4) Keep the road adjacent to the site clean and serviceable at all times to accommodate the passing public, emergency vehicles, school buses, mail carriers, etc. (5) Use necessary means to prevent trucks and other equipment from transporting mud from the site on to the adjacent roadway to such an extent as creates a danger to the passing public. (6) Notify the clerk of the board within three days of the completion of tree removal at each site, whereupon the road superintendent shall inspect the site. Should the road superintendent determine that the road and right-of-way is in as good condition as prior to the commencement of tree removal, then the bond shall be void and the logger's money returned. If corrective repairs are necessary, the reasonable cost thereof shall be deducted from the bond and the remainder, if any, shall be returned to the logger. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 5) Sec. 58-75. - Cessation of operations. The board authorizes the road superintendent to order all logging operations to cease if it is determined that a logger is failing to comply with this article. (Ord. of 5-11-1993, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 62 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30.
